history.content: If you're concerned about perception in industry then both masters' programs are highly respected. I know plenty of alumni from MS and MEng who are in similar places in their careers now, the options that it opens up are relatively similar. However if you're currently a Berkeley student then it makes the most sense to apply for MS. Look at the tuitions for the programs, the MS tuition is similar to undergrad while the MEng has an additional "professional school supplementary tuition". Students who haven't done their undergrad at Berkeley and are interested in an industry-oriented Masters are mainly those who apply to MEng, while fifth-year masters is a better fit (and only available to) people who do their undergrad in Berkeley.

children.subject: In that case i don't think there's too much of a difference between them. A few friends I've had who did MEng and also did the Fung fellowship and they ended up taking some leadership classes, which some people might appreciate but others might dislike bc it comes in the way of taking more techs. Main difference is that 5th year MS does a research thesis final project where as for MEng there is just the Capstone project which (from what I understand) is slightly less intense but still a good amount of work.

@Anon calc The cost is a very valid point but considering that, as an international student, undergrad tuition is even higher than that and 4 years of it no less, I personally don't see the additional "professional school supplementary tuition" as an issue. The main concern I have with the 5th year MS is primarily I don't think I will like doing research and finding an advisor isn't easy in the first place, which is why I am considering MEng instead.

history.content:
I have read some people say that professional degrees like MEng here at Berkeley tend to be "cash grabs". I was wondering how the industry perceives a "professional" masters when compared to a traditional one or two year MS program.

For example, will someone with 5th year MS be perceived differently (by the industry NOT academics/universities) than someone with MEng degree, with preference given to one over the other? Would someone with MEng be able to break into ML Engineering roles at Big N companies that have a masters degree as a minimum requirement?

Personally, curriculum and description wise I find the MEng program to be more appealing because I want to go into the industry. Interested to hear what other people think.
history.subject: Meng perception in the industry
